Row.Text: Boran

Steel yourself, Queen Boran. For in a time of regicide and interregnum, when sitting on the throne is a privilege few would envy, you must assume the mantle of the stalwart ruler. To stabilize the realm, you must reunite and rebuild; to save the dynasty, you must restore its memory. Yours is no easy task. You alone stand between your empire and oblivion.
Boran
Queen of Queens
"Where is that greatness now, your high renown. Your glory and your throne and royal crown?" — the Shahnameh by Abolqasem Ferdowsi

The decline and eventual fall of the Sassanid Empire was a turbulent period during which the throne was victim to the growing power of generals and the ever-present influence of the seven Parthian dynastic families. As such, anyone unfortunate enough to sit on the throne had a hard time of it.

Boran was no exception. She was first crowned as daughter of the late Khosrow II, whose royal blood had been all but snuffed out. This was a time when Shahrbaraz, a general under her father, had seized the throne: a demonstration of just how out-of-control affairs had become. Farrukh Hormuzd, a nobleman belonging to one of the Seven Parthian Houses, had Shahrbaraz murdered, and Boran, who shared blood with Farrukh, was then installed as ruler.

It is possible that her rise to the throne began well before seven-year-old Ardashir III, the rightful heir, was murdered by Shahrbaraz. Her coinage had been issued a year before the deed, so it wouldn't be far-fetched to believe that, in the division and chaos that had the Sassanids on the ropes, Boran had begun her play for regency well before being crowned—perhaps with the backing of the Pahlav.

Boran would witness firsthand the effects of meddling, as her reign would be abruptly truncated, and her deposed, by the very man who had championed her cause. These internal disputes between dynastic families would come to a head with the assassination of Farrukh, who had taken the throne from Boran, by Azarmidukht (Boran's sister and Khosrow II's daughter) and the Parsig faction, and her subsequent murder by Farrukh's son, Rustam, of the Pahlav faction. All the while, Boran would earn her keep as an arbiter between these two powerful families while scheming herself, and in doing so, would reappear on the throne after the murder of her sister.

During her reign, Boran would seek to bring stability to the realm and re-establish the Sassanid Empire by cooperating with Rustam. She recognized the dire condition of her family's legacy, and took measures to restore its authority, even at the concession of her own power. In seeking to remember his glory and revive his memory, she minted coins in the style of her father, Khosrow II. What's more, with these coins she alluded to the long-abandoned legend that designated Sassanid rulers as of the "race of the gods". This was especially important because it hearkened to a title that hadn't been in vogue for centuries. Boran sought to impress upon her people that trespassing on the throne was sacrilege; that the king of kings should once again be extolled properly.

To make matters worse for Boran and the Sassanid Empire, Arab incursions were already underway. During the aforementioned reign of Shahvaraz, strong winds were blowing from the direction of Arabia. So it was all the more important that these quarreling factions set aside their differences and come together for the good of the land. To do this, Boran prevailed upon the Parthian dynasties to take up arms. Her word got through, and Rustam, along with allies from far and wide, rallied to oppose the Arab host. With their alliance came a resounding victory at the Battle of the Bridge. However, the triumph would be short-lived, as their alliance was soon to crumble.
This manifested in a Parsig-backed revolt that culminated in the murder of Boran by the Parsig leader, Firuzan.
Boran is best suited to the sort of player who wants to batten down the hatches. Dig in your heels, influence city-states, and secure your borders.
Drod abar tō, friend. Peace be with you. I am Boran, queen of Iran, daughter of the mighty Khosrow II, and restorer of the race of the Gods.
What say you to the hospitality of our nearest city? There's a ewer of the finest Babylonian wine with your name on it. Or Bazrang if you prefer.
I'd be delighted.
I invite you to witness Ctesiphon in all its splendor, to share with me the vista of cities that have come together to flourish on the Tigris. Would you return the favor?
How can I be of service?
The Keeper of the Curtain will see to it that your delegation observes due protocol.
Now isn't the best time. If it isn't the clergy, it's the courtiers. You know how it is...
Nisaean stallions are prized the world over. All the more reason for you to welcome my delegation.
You have my blessing. Wherever your destination, our waystations will ease the burden of travel.
With the best interests of Iran in mind, I must decline.
My subjects wish to strike out into the world. Will you grant them passage?
We are each of us a lone rider, the horizon our end. So on those rare occasions when our paths converge, we should take comfort in friendship. I accept.
I must decline. Would that I knew you better.
Our achievements are hollow without friends with whom to share them. Shall we then declare our bond?
Terrific.
Very well.
Ally with me, and any who raise sword and spear against the seven climes will tremble before our combined efforts.
Far be it from me to disrupt their gawking, but your troops seem enthralled by my many wonders and walls.
A pleasure doing business with you.
That will not do.
Watch your words. Once spoken, they carry weight. Too heavy, and you will find yourself interred.
Your reign is as backwards and ill-conceived as a div, you toenail-swallowing fool. (Denounces You.)
Your march through my realm will be one that is dashed against fortification after fortification, as you'll soon learn.
There comes a time when the arbiter must abandon neutrality to deal with an unruly party. Consider yourself dealt with.
There is no shame in slinking away. I'll allow you your retreat.
I'll oppose you tooth and nail if I must.
The fortunes of war are mercurial at best. At times, even the lion must withdraw. Peace, then?
The ancient heavens turn; kings disappear. Now Ardavan is gone, now Ardeshir. And though our heads reach to the stars, we must at last be humbled in the lowly dust.

Diz

Fort that yields +1 [ICON_Production] Production and +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture. Ranged units exert Zone of Control when stationed on a Diz. Unlocks with the Defensive Tactics civic, and cannot be built adjacent to another Diz.

Diz, the Middle Persian word for castle or fortress, has been used in the broader sense here to cover the many fortifications throughout the Sassanid Empire: waystations, castles, citadels, walls, and more.

Immediately recognizable in Sassanid fortifications is where they differ from their Roman counterparts. Where the Romans favored square plans with square towers situated in the middle of a wall, Sassanids were varied, especially in adapting to the terrain, and their plans included heavy, strongly projecting, semicircular or parabolic towers situated at the corners of their fortifications.

Sprawling as the empire was, these fortifications served an important purpose. In the form of waystations established every 25–30 kilometers, they eased minds and encouraged trade. They allowed the empire's frontiers to resist invaders until a rebuttal could be set in motion. This abundance of fortifications, however, served as a double-edged blade to be taken advantage of by rebellions and revolts.

Most notable were the limes and walls that limned the borders of the Sassanid Empire. To the north, in the Caucasus, there was the Wall of Derbent and Caspian Gate; to the west, there were fortified cities and defenses against Rome; to the southwest, there was the Wall of the Arabs; to the northeast, the Great Wall of Gorgan; to the southeast, bulwarks in and around Sistan.

In his recent essay "If these Walls Could Speak: The Barrier of Alexander, Wall of Darband and Other Defensive Moats", Touraj Daryaee proposes a symbolic and psychological meaning to Sassanid fortifications; that they symbolized a garden or orchard: an enclosure for the glory of the empire that protected it from those who would wish it harm. They encouraged a sense of community and cultural identity. What's more, it established those beyond the wall as the "other," as expressed in Eran and An-Eran.
